Tens of millions of people are curious about how to properly dice an onion, according to YouTube.
In 2021, renowned chef / food journalist J. Kenji L√≥pez-Alt broke out some math to optimize a technique for getting uniform piece sizes. How does it work?

hed: Dicing an Onion, The Mathematically Optimal Way

story.value: This is an onion. It‚Äôs also a series of concentric circles. What‚Äôs the best way to cut it? That is, how do we get the most uniform piece size?
The average onion has 7-13 layers. For the sake of example, let‚Äôs assume our onion has 10 layers.
Let‚Äôs try a common approach - <mark>all vertical cuts</mark>.
The pieces near the center line are fairly consistent in shape and size.
But along the bottom there are some noticeably larger pieces. When you dice an onion, you‚Äôre probably not imagining pieces like these.
This inconsistency can be measured by calculating the standard deviation of our pieces‚Äô areas. A higher value means a greater variation in piece size.

value.caption: Adjust the slider to see how the standard deviation changes with the number of cuts.

story.value: Okay, let‚Äôs try a different technique - <mark>radial cuts</mark>.
The piece size still isn‚Äôt very consistent - those near the outside are much larger than those near the center.
How does the standard deviation of pieces cut radially compare to those cut vertically?
The standard deviation when cutting radially is greater (57.735% versus 37.304%), which means that our piece size is less consistent.
But we can improve the radial cut strategy. Kenji claims that the most uniform pieces can be produced by aiming at a point ~60% of the onion‚Äôs radius below the cutting surface.
The pieces now look more consistent, except for a few smaller ones along the bottom.
Does the math confirm ~60% depth as the superior technique? Indeed, 34.485% is the smallest standard deviation we‚Äôve seen so far.
Dr. Dylan Poulsen, associate professor of mathematics at Washington College, found that the ideal ‚Äúonion constant‚Äù is about ~55.731% depth.
But we can improve the radial cut strategy even more!

Dr. Poulsen‚Äôs analysis is based on making infinitely many cuts into an onion with infinitely many layers. The diagrams from Kenji‚Äôs claim show 10 cuts being made into an onion with 10 layers. How can we optimize that?
<mark>would another visualization help here?</mark>
When making 10 cuts into a 10-layer onion, the smallest standard deviation occurs when making radial cuts aimed 96% of the onion‚Äôs radius below the cutting surface.

story.value: Insights
* It turns out that making horizontal cuts almost never helps with consistency.
* Radial cuts are usually more consistent than vertical cuts, but you have to aim below the center of the onion.
* The ideal radial depth varies, but it‚Äôs always ‚â•48%. (Recall that this converges to the ‚Äúonion constant‚Äù of ~55.731%, mentioned above.)

conclusion.value: Armed with this knowledge, we can apply the optimal dicing strategy to any onion. ü•∑But how big a difference does being mathematically optimal make? We got in touch with Kenji to find out.

It matters* far more for winning internet debates and solving interesting math problems than it does for cooking. For home cooks, having onion dice that are a little off from perfect is not really an issue anyone should seriously worry about.
